reference: This is a typical clinical manifestation of basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the skin, usually originating from basal cells beneath the epidermis. It typically presents as irregular nodules or patches on the local skin, often accompanied by dilated blood vessels. The surface of the lesion is usually smooth with exudative crusts. Basal cell carcinoma grows slowly, has a good prognosis, but if not treated promptly, it may invade deeper tissues and cause serious consequences.

reference: Fibroma is a benign tumor of the connective tissue that typically grows in the skin or superficial tissues. The tumor usually has a smooth surface, feels soft to the touch, and is generally painless. Fibromas can occur at any age but are more common in young to middle-aged adults. reference: Erythema multiforme is a common skin condition characterized by the presence of polymorphic erythematous patches, vesicles, and plaques on the skin. These lesions often exhibit target-like changes, with central vesicles surrounded by a red ring, accompanied by itching. The causes of erythema multiforme are diverse and may be related to factors such as infection, drug allergies, and autoimmune conditions. The diagnosis of erythema multiforme requires a combination of the patient's clinical presentation, medical history, and characteristics of the skin lesions, and may involve adjunctive tests such as skin biopsies.

The most common first-line treatments for acne vulgaris are topical retinoids, antibiotics, and anti-inflammatory agents. Compound nevi have both melanocytes and keratinocytes, while intranuclear nevi only contain melanocytes. The clinical features of melanocytic nevi include color, shape, size, symmetry, distribution, and morphology. The color of melanocytic nevi is usually brown or black, and the shape is often round or oval. The size is generally less than 6 mm, and the surface is smooth. Question: What are the key differences between a macule and a papule in dermatological descriptions?
A macule is a localized area of skin color change that is flat and lacks a visible surface elevation. A papule, on the other hand, is a raised area of skin that is firm to the touch and has a distinct surface elevation compared to the surrounding skin. The primary distinction lies in the surface morphology: a macule is planar while a papule is elevated. This difference is crucial for accurate clinical diagnosis and treatment planning.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin disease characterized by symmetrical red patches covered with silver-white scales. The nummular form is one of the common clinical types of psoriasis. Treatment options typically include topical therapy, systemic therapy, and phototherapy. Topical treatments such as corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, and vitamin D analogs are commonly used first-line therapies. The choice of treatment depends on the severity and type of psoriasis.
